Topic.Title: US Government approves Softbank acquisition of Sprint

Message.Msg: The deal still has to get shareholder approval. The US Government approval means the unknown for shareholders and company have been removed. Dish is still beating their drum that this sale is a breach of national security. This approval says "no its not".

Topic.Title: "Yahoo’s Bid for Hulu in $600M to $800M Range — Even as It Preps Other Big Deals in Mobile and Communications"

Message.Msg: Interesting times indeed. What was the word that was thrown around during the 90's about the Internet - Dis-intermediate? Taking out the middle men in other words. The publishers are already merging and they have only begun to cut costs. Still their revenue is growing. As for DISH. If they don't get Sprint and I don't see how they can, I could see them making a move on Globalstar. GSAT is trying to get the feds permission to use its frequencies in conjunction with cell phone operators. That would free up a lot of spectrum.

Message.Title: OUCH!!! Neither Fannie Mae nor Freddie Mac can build capital,
Message.Msg: Under the bailout's terms, there's no mechanism for the GSEs to exit conservatorship. Neither Fannie Mae nor Freddie Mac can build capital, because Treasury takes virtually all of their quarterly profits as dividend payment

Topic.Title: News Forums censored

Message.Msg: You hit post then reload the list and it was not posted. Whether it was posted immediately then removed or not posted at all, it is censorship of the worst kind. It happened a lot with the GMO discussion, and discussions about Newtown and Aurora. Certain words are filtered and deletes the whole comment. Words that are not listed as violations.

Topic.Title: Is Yahoo the New Purveyor of Porn?

Message.Msg: "I think the richness and breadth of content available on Tumblr- even though it may not be as brand safe as what's on our site- is what's really exciting and allows us to reach even more users" Those were the comments of CEO Mayer responding to a question in a conference call regarding Yahoo's recent Tumblr acquisition. Remarkably, it appears Yahoo is using their brand and credibility to give legitimacy to online porn and is doing it with alacrity. I'm not sure that this is what Yahoo leadership wanted to communicate, but this is the message that is being conveyed. And it's doubtful that the fawning analyst community and media are going to ask any difficult questions. It is my understanding, that any child can fudge their age and sign up for an account and then obtain unfettered access to unfiltered porn. Is this correct? Can Yahoo ensure the public that no underage children are signing up for accounts and visiting Tumblr's porn and sex sites? How does this comport with Yahoo's written code of ethics in which they desire to protect children and communities? Where are Yahoo's founders? Are they ok with all this? The iconic brand that they built is in jeopardy of being tarnished if this issue is not addressed.

Topic.Title: Is Yahoo the New Purveyor of Porn?

Message.Msg: J R, you can make a personal choice to not open a porn site. Think in terms of what brings revenue to the company vs nit-picking.

Topic.Title: US Government approves Softbank acquisition of Sprint

Message.Msg: Dish Tops Sprint's Bid for Clearwire May 29, 2013 7:57 PM EDT Dish Network Corp (NASDAQ:DISH)said it raised its offer for Clearwire Corp (NASDAQ:CLWR) to $4.40 per share in cash, topping Sprint Nextel Corp's (NYSE:S) bid. Sprint raised its buyout offer for wireless service provider Clearwire to $3.40 per share on May 21 under pressure from activist shareholders.
